Mission Context (partial): Instruction: Tell me who the first three countries to give women the vote were. Give it to me in a bulleted list.... Initial Core Idea from ROT (partial): Okay, I understand the task. Based on my knowledge of historical data, here's the bulleted list of the first three countries to grant women the right to vote:  *   New Zealand (1893) *   Australia (1902) *   Finland (1906)... Initial Core Idea from GOT (partial): Okay, here's the expanded list, specifying the type of voting right and including initial limitations:  Here are the first three countries to grant women the right to **vote** in national elections, along with the year and initial limitations:  *   **New Zealand (1893):** New Zealand granted women the right to vote in parliamentary elections. However, they did not have the right to stand for election until 1919. There were no property or racial restrictions for women to vote, unlike some other countries at the time.  *   **Australia (1902):** The Commonwealth Franchise Act of 1902 granted women the right to vote and stand for election in federal elections. However, this right was explicitly denied to Aboriginal women (and men) in most states. Some states already allowed women to vote in state elections before 1902, but the federal act unified the right, albeit with the Indigenous exclusion.  *   **Finland (1906):** Finland (then an autonomous Grand Duchy under the Russian Empire) granted women the right to both vote and stand for election in parliamentary elections. There were no explicit property or racial restrictions. It was a universal and equal suffrage in that women could vote on the same terms as men. ... The debate will now commence focusing on these ideas.
